Fixed Java compiler warning in ParentRunner.

title: Extending and Modifying sorting feature of JUnit4.
body:
Adding SortWith Annotation to JUnit4 such that test methods defined in a
test class or test classes defined in a test suite can be executed in a
predefined order.

There are four sorting methods available currently for choosing. They are
default, jvm, name ascending and random. First three methods works exactly
as same as their ancestors defined in MethodSorter class. Random sorting
method is added due to the request of adding randomness to tests
execution. A test class annotated with random sorting method executes its
test methods in a random order. A test suites annotated with random
sorting method executes its test classes in a random order.

User still could specify sorting method manually by designating a sorting
request. Also the manually specified sorting method will override all
declarative sorting method defined previously.

Currently I disabled MethodSorter class temporarily because I think if
this patch was accepted, it would no longer be useful.

BTW this is my first attempt to be part of an open source project hence I
might omit something important. Please spare me in advance if I did
something wrong.

Description Builder for JUnit
body:
Continue of pull request #814:

Hi guys.

As of #198, I created a DescriptionBuilder that generates immutable Description classes.

In order to be backward compatible I extended the Description class with two new classes SuiteDescription & TestDescription that represent the two parts. In order to create a SuiteDescription you must now provide a list of children, whereas a TestDescription is generated without.

I didn't make use of the annotations, as it felt wrong and way to complicated to do so. With the builder pattern we can add individual attributes without blowing up the number of constructors. Moreover, clients may write their own builders and create subclasses of SuiteDescription or TestDescription for their own needs.

I think this is a solution that we can live with for a long time.

What I don't like is, that I needed to override the addChild() method to throw an Exception in order to make the subtypes immutable. Even though the addChild() method is marked deprecated and I added a warning JavaDoc for this, maybe there is a better way to solve this. Let me know if so.

I am looking forward to hearing your feedback.

All the best
bechte

title: Assert.assertCollectionEquals()
body:
This new assertion method asserts that the actual collection
- returns the same size() as the expected collection
- its iterator returns the same elements in the same order as the expected collection's iterator

I find myself often creating an expected List in my test using Arrays.asList() but the actual collection is an ArrayList instance. In such cases this new assertion method is useful.

The formal parameter types are Collection-s and not List-s therefore assertCollectionEquals() can be used to assert on SortedMap.keySet() values too.

title: Description.getMethodName() returns null when parameterized test contains line terminators in name
Timeout @Rule and @Test(timeout = ...) behave differently
body: The Timeout @Rule appears to include @Before and @After methods, but the timeout parameter to the @Test annotation does not.

title: ParentRunner swallows AssumptionViolationExceptions and notifies as ignored instead of skipped
body:
The ParentRunner.run(RunNotifier) method catches AssumptionViolationExceptions but fires the notifier for testIgnored rather than notifying for a failed assumption. If a @ClassRule of @BeforeClass throws an AssumptionViolationException, a RunListener is unable to get access to the exception.

It seems possible that this was done by design. I did not find an open discussion on this, but it is possible that I'm not looking in the correct place.

title: #892 Description.getMethodName() should not return null
body:
Hi,

As described in #892
Description.getMethodName() returns null when parametrized test contains "\n" symbols.

Proposed simple fix to avoid such behavior.

Thanks.

title: ParentRunner handling of AssumptionViolationException
body:
The ParentRunner class swallows AssumptionViolationExceptions in the run(RunNotifier) method by letting it fall out of scope treating the evaluation as an ignored test rather than a skipped test.

Most RunListeners that I have seen (including the maven-surefire-plugin) treat skipped and ignored tests the same, but custom run listeners that have different behavior for testIgnored(Description) and testAssumptionFailure(Failure) are missing the information encapsulated in the AssumptionViolationException.

The behavior in the runLeaf(Statement, Description, Notifier) does pass the AssumptionViolationException on by firing the failed assumption method to the notifier, which does make me suspect that the behavior in the parent run method was simply overlooked.

A basic use case that I personally use: @BeforeClass method that checks a system and determines that the tests in the class will provide no meaningful results. An AssumptionViolationException is thrown. A custom run listener is used to distinguish the differences between @Ignored tests and tests that have had been marked with assumption failures.

title: Allow higher JDK version with Java compiler 1.5
body:
The JDK 5 and JDK 6 are discontinued.
Allow JDK 8 which brings more features (-Xdoclint and javadoc).
Still compile all sources with Java 5 Compiler (javac -source 1.5 -target 1.5 ...).
Testing Lambda in integration tests built with Java 8: assertThat(Callable, returns...).
Enables me to use Java Service Loader from Java  6 in integration tests.

title: Description.getMethodName() should not return null. Fixes #892

title: Support to allow the Timeout @Rule to become disabled when debugging without modification to the test class
body:
Feature to disable the Timeout @rule when the test class being ran has been launched in debug mode. Allowing users to debug their tests without the timeout firing. This feature may be disabled by calling Timeout.whenDebugging(true) which forces the timeout to fire even during debugging.

Timeouts or time sensitive logic in the code under test is not handled by this feature and may make this unuseful in some circumstances. The important benefit of this feature is that you can suspend timeouts without any making any modifications to your test class to remove them during debugging. Anecdotally removing timeouts for debug purposes often results in developers forgetting to restore them.

In this pull-request I've enabled the feature by default. There is perhaps an argument to disable it by default and allow users to opt-in. I'm very open to discussion on this.

This feature somewhat relates to this https://github.com/junit-team/junit/issues/738

I've tried to keep as close to the JUnit projects conventions but please let me know if there is anything you'd prefer to be changed.

title: junit as osgi bundle
body:
This PR
+ generates new osgi manifest headers
+ Maven build uses the same Java Hamcrest dependency as before
+ manifest implementation entries moved from maven-jar-plugin to maven-bundle-plugin
+ added integration tests which say that the osgi bundle has correct configuration
